articles.headline: How Google Protected Andy Rubin, the ‘Father of Android’
articles.snippet: The internet giant paid Mr. Rubin $90 million and praised him, while keeping silent about a misconduct claim.
articles.abstract: The internet giant paid Mr. Rubin $90 million and praised him, while keeping silent about a misconduct claim.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google gave Andy Rubin, the creator of Android mobile software, a hero’s farewell when he left the company in October 2014.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Katie Benner

articles.headline: A.I. Is Helping Scientists Predict When and Where the Next Big Earthquake Will Be
articles.snippet: Scientists have a miserable record of predicting where and when earthquakes will strike. Some are now turning to artificial intelligence for answers.
articles.abstract: Scientists have a miserable record of predicting where and when earthquakes will strike. Some are now turning to artificial intelligence for answers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Countless dollars and entire scientific careers have been dedicated to predicting where and when the next big earthquake will strike. But unlike weather forecasting, which has significantly improved with the use of better satellites and more powerful mathematical models, earthquake prediction has been marred by repeated failure.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Cade Metz

articles.headline: CBS Inquiry Into What Went Wrong in Les Moonves Era Hits Snags as It Advances
articles.snippet: Investigators have interviewed more than 250 people as they examine allegations of misconduct. But not every accuser has been contacted, and some are hesitant to cooperate.
articles.abstract: Investigators have interviewed more than 250 people as they examine allegations of misconduct. But not every accuser has been contacted, and some are hesitant to cooperate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The #MeToo movement may have affected the CBS Corporation more than any other mass media company over the past year. After The New Yorker and The Washington Post published articles detailing accusations against high-ranking men at the network, CBS parted ways with Leslie Moonves, its chief executive; Jeff Fager, the longtime executive producer of “60 Minutes”; and Charlie Rose, one of its best known anchors.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Charged Ahead in the Third Quarter
articles.snippet: After six months of strong growth, the economy is on track for its best annual performance since 2005. But there were signs of a slowdown ahead.
articles.abstract: After six months of strong growth, the economy is on track for its best annual performance since 2005. But there were signs of a slowdown ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy barreled ahead in the third quarter as consumers stepped up and spent more, keeping it on track for the best annual performance since 2005.

articles.headline: The Tragedy of Saudi Arabia’s War in Yemen
articles.snippet: The Khashoggi killing has cast light on Saudi tactics in Yemen, where an economic war has pushed millions to the brink of starvation.
articles.abstract: The Khashoggi killing has cast light on Saudi tactics in Yemen, where an economic war has pushed millions to the brink of starvation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Khashoggi killing has cast light on Saudi tactics in Yemen, where an economic war has pushed millions to the brink of starvation.

articles.headline: Stacey Abrams, a Daughter of the South, Asks Georgia to Change
articles.snippet: In an election steeped in issues of race, voting rights and the South’s past, present and future, Ms. Abrams is trying to become the first black woman elected governor of any state.
articles.abstract: In an election steeped in issues of race, voting rights and the South’s past, present and future, Ms. Abrams is trying to become the first black woman elected governor of any state.
articles.lead_paragraph: THOMASVILLE, Ga. — Let’s say you were making a TV movie about Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor in the reliably Republican state of Georgia. Where would you begin?
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: Trump’s Complaint: Bomb Plot Coverage Overtakes His Campaign Rhetoric
articles.snippet: President Trump said it was “very unfortunate” that news organizations were not talking about politics and instead were focused on pipe bombs mailed to his critics.
articles.abstract: President Trump said it was “very unfortunate” that news organizations were not talking about politics and instead were focused on pipe bombs mailed to his critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took the podium in the East Room on Friday, he opened with a solemn expression of gratitude to the F.B.I. and other law enforcement agencies for arresting a suspect in a bomb plot against prominent Democrats and other critics of him.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Katie Rogers
